# Git


## clean 

> the best way is to delete the folder and clone again

### clean changes & files

```bash
git reset --hard	# revert all modified files.

git clean -fd		# remove all untracked files and directories.
```

### untrack files

```bash
git rm --cached path/to/file
git update-index --assume-unchanged path/to/file
```

### remove big files

`git-rm-big path/to/file`

### GC
git gc --aggressive --prune=all



## config, alias


### list alias

`git help co`




## Trouble shooting

### push a project to an existing GitHub repo

> When you want to push a local repo to GitHub, remember to create an _empty_ GitHub repo.

If you don't follow the guide, I recommend you delete the repo and create a new one. 

The following code serves as the last choice

```bash
git commit --allow-empty
git branch --set-upstream-to=origin/master master
git pull --allow-unrelated-histories
```
